Keywords: nanomaterials, combined treatments, toxicity, biomarkers of exposure, Cucurbita 21 pepo. 22
23
Abstract 24
Although engineered nanomaterial (ENM) uptake, transport and response mechanisms in plants 25 have received increased attention in the recent years, many questions regarding ENM risks to the 26 environment and to food safety remain unanswered. The impact of ENM interactions with co-27 existing organic/inorganic contaminants, including secondary ENMs, remains poorly understood. 28 The physiological and molecular response of zucchini (Cucurbita pepo L.) under conditions of 29 nanomaterial combined treatments (NMCT) with binary combinations of nanoparticle (NP) 30 cerium oxide (CeO2), lanthanum oxide (La2O3), copper oxide (CuO), zinc oxide (ZnO) (500 mg 31
L −1 ) and cadmium sulfide quantum dots (CdS QDs) (100 mg L −1 ) were tested (for 21 days, in 32 vermiculite) and compared with respective individual (NMIT) and bulk material (BMT) 33 treatments. ICP-MS results within specific tissues upon exposure to NMCT or NMIT 34 demonstrated that metal content varied significantly upon co-exposure, including instances of 35 antagonistic effects: La uptake was significantly decreased (50~80%, compared to NMIT or to 36 NMCT) upon CeO2 NP co-exposure whereas La2O3 NP caused a complete deregulation (2~5-37 fold higher) of Cu uptake upon CuO NP co-exposure. Expression analysis of genes previously 38 shown as responsive to ENM exposure confirmed the involvement of the chloroplast in plant 39 response: ORF31, an electron carrier down-regulated in all treatments, showed potential as a 40 biomarker of exposure/effect. Principal component analysis on plant physiological and molecular 41 response provided insight into the nature of phytotoxicity under NMIT and NMCT. This 42

45
Environmental significance 46
CeO2, La2O3, CuO, ZnO NPs, and CdS QDs are currently used in a broad range of applications, 47 including agriculture, but the impacts of these ENMs on the environment and the risk posed from 48 exposure remains unclear. This project seeks to correlate the molecular and physiological 49 response of a model crop species, zucchini (Cucurbita pepo L.), to combinations of five ENMs 50 with the individual ENMs treatment or the corresponding bulk materials. Genes specifically 51 triggered upon exposure to combinations of ENMs were compared to those impacted upon single 52 analyte exposure. The study offers a holistic interpretation of the affected regulatory networks 53 under these exposure scenarios and provides important information in support of risk assessment 54 efforts. 55
56
Introduction 57
The global impacts of nanotechnology are dramatically influencing sectors such as 58 electronics, medicine, health care, communications, food and agriculture. As far as food and 59 nutrition are concerned, nanotechnologies include areas such as packaging and biosensors to 60 enhance the shelf life of the products and to detect the presence of chemical contaminants or 61
pathogenic microorganisms. 1 Areas related to improved food production such as nanopesticides, 62 nanofertilizers, or to reduce and treat agro-wastes are also of interest. In this context, 63

nanotechnology has tremendous potential to address the challenges facing global food 64 production, including a changing climate and continuing population increases. 2 Thus, a 65 mechanistic understanding of the fate and effects of engineered nanomaterials (ENMs) in the 66 environment and in food crops is critical to the safe and sustainable application of 67
nanotechnology. 3,4 68
Significant progress has been made recently to understand ENMs physico-chemical 69 behavior in the environment, 5 and the mechanisms underlying the physiological response of 70
different model organisms and in select complex ecological systems. 6-10 Recent studies 71 specifically focused on terrestrial plants give an informative picture of the uptake, transport and 72
toxicity mechanisms of some commonly used ENMs. 11-13 Other studies have investigated the fate 73
and effects of ENMs in the rhizosphere. 14,15 However, important questions remain unanswered, 74 including impacts on food safety, and the influence of co-contamination of different organic and 75
inorganic compounds on overall exposure and risk. 16 Environmental exposure to nanomaterial 76 combined treatment (NMCT) is discussed in a number of preliminary studies on 77
microorganisms, 17,18 plants 19,20 and animals. 21 Importantly, the application of nanotechnology to 78
agriculture and food safety remain areas in need of more intense study, 22 including an assessment 79 of environmental and health implications. 80
The aim of the present study was to characterize the response of zucchini (Cucurbita 81 pepo L.) to NMCT of five metal-based and rare earth metal-based nanomaterials as compared to 82 individual ENM treatment (NMIT) and treatments with corresponding bulk materials (BMT). By 83 analyzing and comparing the physiological and molecular responses, interpreted with a systems 84 biology (holistic) approach, our study offers an overview of NMCT and, more generally, of 85 ENM contamination in plants. Nanoparticle (NP) oxides of cerium (CeO2), lanthanum (La2O3), 86

copper (CuO), and zinc (ZnO), as well as cadmium sulfide quantum dots (CdS QDs), were 87 chosen based on their frequent application not only in electronics, cosmetics, medicine, but also 88
in food production and agriculture. 23 NMCT data can be directly compared with results obtained 89 in previous study involving zucchini with individual exposure to CeO2, La2O3 and CuO NP, and 90
with their corresponding bulk materials. 24 The use of ZnO NPs and CdS QDs were functional to 91 increase the information related to metal oxides-based ENMs and to compare the QDs results 92 obtained in A. thaliana with another plant as C. pepo, respectively. Plant physiological and 93 molecular responses to NMCT were correlated with the metal content of the different plant 94
tissues. A transcription profiling analysis of candidates genes obtained in previous analyses 7,24 95 was used to distinguish the genes specifically impacted during the different ENM exposure 96 (univocal genes) from those redundant across the different types on ENMs (non-univocal genes). 97 A gene consistently affected across treatments was identified as potential biomarker of ENM 98 exposure and effect. 99
Methods 100
ENM characterization and experimental design 101
Zinc oxide (ZnO) and cerium oxide (CeO2) nanopowders were purchased from Sigma-102 Aldrich (St. Louis, MO). Lanthanum oxide (La2O3) and copper oxide (CuO) nanopowders were 103 purchased from U.S. Research Nanomaterials, Inc. (Houston, TX). CdS QDs were provided and 104 characterized by IMEM-CNR (Parma, IT); equivalent ZnO and CdS bulk materials were 105 purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, MO). 106
CdS QDs were synthesized according to Villani et al. (2012). 25 X-Ray diffraction (XRD) 107 was performed with a Thermo ARL X’tra diffractometer (Cu K α source, θ - θ Bragg-Brentano 108

Grain size 110 was estimated by Scherrer calculation on FWHM of the main peak is 4 nm. QDs were dispersed 111 onto Cu/lacey-carbon TEM grids and characterized by a field emission high resolution (Scherzer 112 resolution about 0.19 nm) analytical TEM working at 200 kV (JEOL JEM-2200 FS). The S/TEM 113 image reported in Figure S2a confirms the QDs size deduced from Scherrer, and HREM 114 confirmed the hexagonal phase of CdS QDs (Figure S2b). Nanoparticle (NP) and QDs in 115 deionized water were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (Hitachi 116 HT7700, Hitachi High Technologies America, Pleasanton, CA), as well as for zeta (ζ) potential 117 and average particle size (dh) by Zetasizer Nano Series ZS90, Malvern Instruments, Malvern, 118 UK (Table 1). TEM samples were prepared using a glutaraldehyde/osmium tetroxide protocol, as 119
reported in Pagano et al. (2016). 24 Ultra-thin sections were prepared by Leica EM UC7 120 ultramicrotome (Leica Microsystems Inc., Buffalo Grove, IL). Samples were transferred to Au 121 grids (Electron Microscopy Sciences, Hatfield, PA) and analyzed by transmission elector 122 microscope (TEM) Hitachi HT7700. A TEM image related to ZnO NPs is reported in Figure S3 123
whereas CeO2, La2O3 and CuO NPs are reported from Pagano et al. (2016). 24 124 125

Zucchini seeds (Cucurbita pepo L.; cv Costata Romanesco) were purchased from 131 Johnny’s Selected Seeds (Albion, ME). Plants were grown and exposed to NMIT and NMCT as 132
described in Pagano et al. (2016). 24 Seeds were germinated in vermiculite for 7 d and were then 133
transferred into 30 g (200 mL) of vermiculite containing a solution of 0 mg L −1 (untreated 134
control) or 500 mg L −1 of ZnO bulk or NPs. The concentration used for ZnO NP or bulk 135
treatment (500 mg L −1 ) was chosen in order to compare the data obtained with other metal oxide 136
based nanomaterials (CeO2, La2O3, CuO NPs) analyzed in Pagano et al. (2016). 24 For CdS QDs 137
or bulk particles, the concentration used was 100 mg L −1 according to Marmiroli et al. (2014). 7 138 Nanomaterial combined treatments (NMCTs) were performed with all the 10 possible binary 139
combinations of CeO2, La2O3, CuO, ZnO NPs (500 mg L −1 ; 100 mg of NPs per pot) and CdS 140
QDs (100 mg L −1 ; 20 mg of QDs per pot), in nine replicates for each treatment. Bulk and NP 141 solutions were sonicated at 40% amplitude for 60-120 s by Fisher Scientific Model 505 Sonic 142 Dismembrator (Waltham, MA) to reduce particle aggregation. For all experiments, seedlings 143 were grown for 21 d at 24°C, with a relative humidity of 30%, and a 16 h photoperiod (light 144
intensity 120 µM m −2 s −1 photosynthetic photon flux). Tap water was administered to plants for 145 the total 28 d of the experiment. All the analyses were performed using the same experimental 146 design. 147
148 Physiological analysis and metal content 149 Plants harvested during vegetative growth were thoroughly washed with DI water to 150 remove residual particles or vermiculite. Primary roots and shoots length, as well as total fresh 151 biomass, were measured. Photosynthesis efficiency was estimated with a quantification of 152 chlorophyll a (662 nm), chlorophyll b (645 nm) and carotenoids (470 nm), following Ni et al. 153

Three biological replicates (0.2 g of fresh plant material) 156 were evaluated, in three technical replicates. The dry tissue mass of separated roots, stems and 157 leaves (60°C for 48 h) were determined on five independent replicates. Digestion of 0.1 g of 158 sample was conducted in 2.5 mL of 65% HNO3 for 45 min at 115°C; 1 mL of 30% H2O2 was 159 added prior to an additional 20 min at 115°C in a SCP Science DigiPREP MS digestor (SCP 160 SCIENCE, Baie D’Urfé, Quebec, CND). The resulting solution was diluted to a final volume of 161 50 mL prior to analysis on an Agilent ICP-MS 7500ce (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA). 162 Quantification of Ce (140 amu), La (139 amu), Cu (63 amu), Zn (66 amu), Cd (111 amu) was 163 done with a four-point calibration curve based on standard reference materials (SPEX CertiPrep, 164 Metuchen, NJ). 165
166 Gene expression analysis 167 Total RNA was extracted from 0.1 g of fresh plant material (derived from the whole 168
plant), following Pagano et al. (2016), 24 using a Sigma-Aldrich Spectrum Plant Total RNA Kit 169 (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO). Three biological replicates per treatment were extracted. Total 170 RNA quality and quantity was assessed by gel electrophoresis and by determining 260/280 ratio 171 with a Thermo Scientific Nanodrop Lite Spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, 172 Wilmington, DE). A two-step reverse transcription was performed on 1 µg of the total RNA 173 extracted using the Qiagen QuantiTect Reverse Transcription kit (Qiagen, Velno, NL). 174 Quantitative PCR (qPCR) was conducted in a Bio-Rad SsoAdvanced Universal SYBR Green 175 Supermix in an optical 96 well plate with the Bio-Rad CFX96 Touch Real-Time PCR Detection 176

(2016). 24 The gene 178 selection was derived from previous study in A. thaliana 7 and genes are represented as up- or 179 down-regulated (“u” or “d”). The qPCR condition was: 95°C for 10’, 95°C for 15”, and 60°C for 180 60” for 40 cycles. For each qPCR reaction, the Tm curve first derivative was calculated as 181 amplification control. Gene expression was quantified through ∆∆Ct method using β-actin of C. 182 pepo as the housekeeping gene. 183
184
Statistics, bioinformatics and system biology analysis 185
A one-way ANOVA with Tukey’s (HSD) pairwise multiple comparison test (Systat 186 SigmaPlot 13.0), was used for biomass, moisture content, root/shoot length and metal content 187 analysis (on log transformed data). A two-tail Student t test was applied to qPCR results, as well 188 as to photosynthetic efficiency and cell viability assays. The R software (https://www.r-189 project.org/) was used for the gene clustering and principal component analysis (PCA). Venny 190 bioinformatics tool (http://bioinfogp.cnb.csic.es/tools/venny/) for the generation of Venn 191 diagrams. For multiple comparisons, “chord diagrams” were constructed through the Circos 192
Table Viewer tool (http://mkweb.bcgsc.ca/tableviewer/). Gene Ontology (GO) network analysis 193 was performed by the GeneMANIA data service (http://www.genemania.org/). 194

Results and discussion 199
200 Physiological measurements and Biomass Differential Effect (BDE) index analysis 201
Results from these analyses are reported in Tables S2-S4 and Figures S4-S5. At harvest 202 the average biomass of control plants was 4.05 g; significant reductions in plant biomass were 203
evident upon exposure to bulk ZnO at 500 mg L −1 (-47.4%) and CdS QDs at 100 mg L −1 (-204 21.9%). The leaf moisture content of zucchini exposed to bulk ZnO (+84%) and of root length 205
for NP ZnO (500 mg L −1 ) (+37%) were both significantly increased compared to non-amended 206 plants. The other treatments did not show any significant difference (Table S2). 207
In general, results from the NMCTs showed a reduced effect on plant growth and 208 moisture content (Table S3). Control plants had an average wet biomass of 2.86 g and exposure 209 to binary NM caused a biomass increase of 46 and 37.8% for the treatments with CeO2+CuO NP 210
and La2O3+ZnO NP (500 mg L −1 , for each NP), respectively, and a reduction of 23.4% for the 211 CeO2 NP + CdS QDs treatment (Table S3a) as compared to the untreated plants. Moisture 212 content in the control leaves was 22.3% and the only significant decrease occurred with the 213 CeO2+CuO NP treatment (-40% as compared to other binary treatments). Plant root length was 214 unaffected by NMCT whereas shoot length significantly increased (13-25%) by exposure to 215
CeO2+CuO NP, CeO2+ZnO NP, CuO+ZnO NP (500 mg L −1 , for each NP) and La2O3 NP + CdS 216
QD (500 and 100 mg L −1 , respectively) as compared to other combined treatments. However, 217 only the La2O3+ZnO NP treatment yielded an increase on the unamended controls (Table S3). 218 Analyses of the effects on photosynthetic activity and cell viability did not show any significant 219 changes, as measured by chlorophyll a, chlorophyll b, carotenoids or formazan content. exception was the CuO+ZnO NP treatment, which showed a formazan increase of 91% over the 221 controls (Figure S4). 222
To summarize the effects of BMT and NMCT and interpret their relationship with the 223 effects of NMIT, a Biomass Differential Effect (BDE) index was calculated using biomass 224 variation ratios as reference parameters (Table S4). The graphical dispersion of BDE data 225 (Figure S5) depicted the proportion of effects related to each bulk material against the 226 corresponding NMIT, but also provided insight into the complex nature of the NMCT interactive 227 effects and the “weight” on the overall effects on plant biomass of the two ENMs combined. 228 Most of the points representing the BDE reported were between 0.75 and 1.25, highlighting how 229 the differences in biomass (normalized to the untreated controls) produced in condition of BMT 230 or NMCT were similar to that observed in NMIT conditions, with several exceptions: in the case 231 of La2O3 and ZnO BDEBMT indexes, the effects of the bulk was higher than the NP treatment, 232 whereas, for CdS there was a significant effect of the NMIT on the BMT. Emblematic was the 233 case of CdS QDs: for BDENMCT indexes that involved QDs the effect of the NMIT was still 234 “dominant” to the combined one. Partial confirmation of this was observed in the combination of 235 CeO2 NP + CdS QD, in which the NMCT effect was “dominant” to the CeO2 NMIT, thus, 236 highlighting the greater influence of the CdS QDs. In the case of CeO2+CuO NP treatment, the 237 effect of CuO NMIT was higher than the NMCT. Conversely, CeO2 NP seems to be the less 238 influential in terms of biomass production and therefore more subject to the effect of the second 239 ENM in NMCT conditions. 240

Determination of metal content 243
Zn and Cd content of zucchini exposed to NP/bulk ZnO and QDs/bulk CdS, with the 244 relative statistics, are shown in Figures S6-S7. Root Zn concentrations in the NP and bulk 245
treatments were 9680 and 10700 mg kg -1 , respectively; these values are not significantly 246 different from each other, but are different from the controls. Stem Zn content was similarly 247
unaffected by Zn particle type, with 4310 and 4670 mg kg -1 for the NPs and bulk treatments, 248 respectively. Leaf Zn concentration varied significantly with treatment: NP and bulk exposure 249
yielded 2460 and 935 mg kg -1 , respectively. With CdS QDs and bulk CdS (100 mg L −1 ) 250

Quantitative PCR (qPCR) analysis showed that 21 out of the 38 genes were 294 commonly up- or down-regulated across the two species, as shown in the heatmap and Venn 295 diagram (Figure S8). 296

) and to the binary combination of NP CeO2, La2O3, CuO, ZnO and CdS 298 QDs were compared with those reported in Pagano et al. (2016), which involved CeO2, La2O3 299

Nano and bulk material comparison 365
An evaluation of plant biomass after treatment with NP ZnO, CdS QDs and the 366 corresponding bulk materials showed significant differences, as confirmed by the BDEBMT index 367 analysis (Figure S5). Although Zn content in roots and stems was similar in plants treated with 368 NP or bulk ZnO, more Zn was translocated to the leaves under treatment with ENM (Table S2; 369 Figure S6). Similar results were published for treatments performed in green pea (Pisum sativum 370
L.) 28 and in wheat (Triticum aestivum L.), 29 where the high level of Zn present in the tissues was 371
explained by larger ion dissolution from the ENM. 30 Similarly, the concentration of Cd 372 translocated to stems and leaves in CdS QD treated plants was higher than that observed for the 373 BMT (Table S2; Figure S7). This discrepancy can’t be related to the CdS QDs ion release since 374 the high CdS QD stability. 7 The larger accumulation of Zn as compared with Cd is certainly 375 related to a lower phytotoxicity of ZnO NPs as compared with CdS QDs. 376
The expression analyses conducted on CeO2, La2O3 and CuO NP treatments and 377 corresponding BMTs (Figure S10) offered further evidence of differences between the two types 378

On the other hand, current data from Cd may be biased by the small panel of genes 393 chosen. ENM specific response 434
qPCR analysis performed on zucchini for 38 genes as reported in Pagano et al. (2016) 24 435 permits a transcriptional assessment of plant response to NP exposure, highlighting those genes 436 (univocal and non-univocal) that were specifically involved in the response mechanisms (Table 437 S8). For example, 55% of the genes studied under CdS QDs treatment in C. pepo and A. thaliana 438 showed common (up- or down-) regulation. This demonstrates how CdS QDs exposure across 439 plant species, even those phylogenetically distant, may involve similar response mechanisms 440 (Figure S8). Analysis of genes specifically regulated by ENMs exposure showed several 441 functionalities related to the chloroplast, highlighting the potential of this organelle as a sensitive 442
target. Previously, Wang et al. (2016) 37 reported that CuO NP inhibits specific chloroplast 443 electron carriers, leading to observable phytotoxicity. In this study, the gene 152u (ORF31; a 444 chloroplast electron carrier) was specifically down-regulated in all NMITs and NMCTs (Figure 445 2), making it a potential biomarker of exposure and effects related to ENM treatments. Conclusions 456
For metal-based nanoparticle oxides described in this paper, there is generally conflicting 457 evidence on the toxicity of the ENMs vs bulk materials vs released ions. The traditional example 458
is ZnO NP, which is reported to be toxic as the bulk ZnO to various organisms. 32,40,41 A question 459 frequently asked in nanotoxicology studies is how much of the observed toxicity is due to 460
released ions. ZnO NP treatment has been both reported to be dominated by Zn ion release 30,42 or 461
to have a minor contribution to toxicity; 32 the variability seems to be mainly related to the 462 organism studied. For nano-oxides in general, the release of metal ions is assumed to be less of a 463 concern because of the limited ENM solubility. Importantly, the focus in the current paper was 464 beyond this point and was more concerned with the different physiological and molecular 465 responses upon exposure to NMCT, as compared with NMIT and BMT. Moreover, the relevance 466 of the gene expression in abiotic stress tolerance has been widely acknowledged as a main factor 467
in crop plants yield. 43 Therefore, this paper compares the biological aspects of multiple ENMs 468 exposure, measuring not only toxicity but also plant molecular responsive. This type of exposure 469

has not been previously reported but has relevance since the combination of two or more ENMs 470
may frequently occur in agricultural systems. 44,45 Not surprisingly, the response resulting from 471 NMCT is both complex and dynamic, largely due to the coexistence (in terms of different ratios) 472 of nano and ionic forms derived from ENM dissolution. Their possible interactions depend 473
greatly on the stability, surface area and charge of the ENMs themselves, 18,35 but also on the 474 experimental conditions (hydroponic or natural soil media) or longer time of exposure (e.g. 475 entire life cycle) may change particle/tissues interactions as well as plant uptake and 476
translocation. 9 The relevance of ENMs on plant edible parts, as well as the risk to that related, 477
still need to be fully clarified, even if seems to be highly dependent on dietary intake. 46 478 Furthermore, questions remain over how to assess ion dissolution in realistic environmental 479
exposure scenarios. 47 Considering the complex experimental design and the limited literature 480 available on this object, not enough information is available to provide a priori hypothesis 481 specific to nanoparticle interactions/accumulation and valid modeling with stables parameters to 482 obtain reliable results. Nevertheless, in this complex scenario, several points of interest are worth 483 noting: the effects in zucchini of different NMCTs, as shown by both physiological analysis 484 (summarized by BDE indexes, Figure S5) and molecular analysis (Figure 2), were largely 485 additive; possible synergistic effects of CeO2, La2O3 and CuO NPs are suggested but additional 486 studies are necessary to address this interaction. In order to offer an overall picture NP exposure, 487 a PCA was performed to reduce the complexity of the response and summarizing the obtained 488 results (Figure 4). This analysis highlights the major components involved in NMITs and 489 NMCTs related to biomass, metal uptake and molecular response. Here, 62.1% of the total 490 variance was related to the metal uptake observed, especially in relation to ZnO NP. Also, the 491 impact on gene regulation relative to the different treatments stands out (26.7%), highlighting the 492

metadata.abstractText: 24 Although engineered nanomaterial (ENM) uptake, transport and response mechanisms in plants 25 have received increased attention in the recent years, many questions regarding ENM risks to the 26 environment and to food safety remain unanswered. The impact of ENM interactions with co27 existing organic/inorganic contaminants, including secondary ENMs, remains poorly understood. 28 The physiological and molecular response of zucchini (Cucurbita pepo L.) under conditions of 29 nanomaterial combined treatments (NMCT) with binary combinations of nanoparticle (NP) 30 cerium oxide (CeO2), lanthanum oxide (La2O3), copper oxide (CuO), zinc oxide (ZnO) (500 mg 31 L −1 ) and cadmium sulfide quantum dots (CdS QDs) (100 mg L −1 ) were tested (for 21 days, in 32 vermiculite) and compared with respective individual (NMIT) and bulk material (BMT) 33 treatments. ICP-MS results within specific tissues upon exposure to NMCT or NMIT 34 demonstrated that metal content varied significantly upon co-exposure, including instances of 35 antagonistic effects: La uptake was significantly decreased (50~80%, compared to NMIT or to 36 NMCT) upon CeO2 NP co-exposure whereas La2O3 NP caused a complete deregulation (2~537 fold higher) of Cu uptake upon CuO NP co-exposure. Expression analysis of genes previously 38 shown as responsive to ENM exposure confirmed the involvement of the chloroplast in plant 39 response: ORF31, an electron carrier down-regulated in all treatments, showed potential as a 40 biomarker of exposure/effect. Principal component analysis on plant physiological and molecular 41 response provided insight into the nature of phytotoxicity under NMIT and NMCT.
